summary.para: Represents a time interval.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan object represents a time interval, or duration of time, measured as a positive or negative number of days, hours, minutes, seconds, and fractions of a second. The largest unit of time used to measure duration is a day. Time intervals are measured in days for consistency because the number of days in larger units of time, such as months and years, varies.

The value of a T:System.TimeSpan object is the number of ticks that equal the represented time interval. A tick is equal to 100 nanoseconds, and the value of a T:System.TimeSpan object can range from F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue to F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.

A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. That is, a time interval consists of a positive or negative number of days without a time of day, or a number of days with a time of day, or only a time of day. For example, the text representation of a T:System.TimeSpan object initialized to 1.0e+13 ticks is "11.13:46:40", which means 11 days, 13 hours, 46 minutes, and 40 seconds.
The T:System.TimeSpan type implements the T:System.IComparable and T:System.IComparable`1 interfaces.
The following code example creates several T:System.TimeSpan objects and displays the properties of each.

summary.para: Represents the maximum T:System.TimeSpan value. This field is read-only.

content.para: The value of this field is equivalent to F:System.Int64.MaxValue ticks. The string representation of this value is positive 10675199.02:48:05.4775807.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue field.

summary.para: Represents the minimum T:System.TimeSpan value. This field is read-only.

content.para: The value of this field is equivalent to F:System.Int64.MinValue ticks. The string representation of this value is negative 10675199.02:48:05.4775808.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue field.

summary.para: Represents the number of ticks in 1 day. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 864 billion; that is, 864,000,000,000.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.TicksPerDay field.

summary.para: Represents the number of ticks in 1 hour. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 36 billion; that is, 36,000,000,000.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.TicksPerHour field.

summary.para: Represents the number of ticks in 1 millisecond. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 10 thousand; that is, 10,000.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.TicksPerMillisecond field.

summary.para: Represents the number of ticks in 1 minute. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is 600 million; that is, 600,000,000.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.TicksPerMinute field.

summary.para: Represents the number of ticks in 1 second.

content.para: The value of this constant is 10 million; that is, 10,000,000.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.TicksPerSecond field.

summary.para: Represents the zero T:System.TimeSpan value. This field is read-only.

content.para: This constant provides a convenient source for zero in time calculations.
The following code example references and displays the value of the F:System.TimeSpan.Zero field.

summary.para: Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan.
Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of hours, minutes, and seconds.

content.para: Number of hours.
Number of minutes.
Number of seconds.
The parameters specify a T:System.TimeSpan value less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The specified hours, minutes, and seconds are converted to ticks, and that value initializes this instance.
The following code example creates several T:System.TimeSpan objects using the constructor overload that initializes a T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of hours, minutes, and seconds.

summary.para: Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan.
Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of days, hours, minutes, and seconds.

content.para: Number of days.
Number of hours.
Number of minutes.
Number of seconds.
The parameters specify a T:System.TimeSpan value less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The specified days, hours, minutes, and seconds are converted to ticks, and that value initializes this instance.
The following code example creates several T:System.TimeSpan objects using the constructor overload that initializes a T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of days, hours, minutes, and seconds.

summary.para: Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of days, hours, minutes, seconds, and milliseconds.

content.para: Number of days.
Number of hours.
Number of minutes.
Number of seconds.
Number of milliseconds.
The parameters specify a T:System.TimeSpan value less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The specified days, hours, minutes, seconds, and milliseconds are converted to ticks, and that value initializes this instance.

The following code example creates several T:System.TimeSpan objects using the constructor overload that initializes a T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of days, hours, minutes, seconds, and milliseconds.

summary.para: Initializes a new T:System.TimeSpan to the specified number of ticks.

content.para: A time period expressed in 100-nanosecond units.
The following code example creates several T:System.TimeSpan objects using the constructor overload that initializes a T:System.TimeSpan to a specified number of ticks.

summary.para: Adds the specified T:System.TimeSpan to this instance.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.

returnValue.para: A T:System.TimeSpan that represents the value of this instance plus the value of ts.

content.para: The resulting T:System.TimeSpan is less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The return value must be between F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue and F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The return value is a new T:System.TimeSpan; the original T:System.TimeSpan is not modified.
The following code example creates several pairs of T:System.TimeSpan objects and calculates their sum with the M:System.TimeSpan.Add(System.TimeSpan) method.

summary.para: Compares two T:System.TimeSpan values and returns an integer that indicates their relationship.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.
A T:System.TimeSpan.
The following code example compares several TimeSpan objects to a reference TimeSpan using the Compare method.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or T:System.TimeSpan and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified object and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: An object to compare, or null.

entry.para: The value of this instance is less than the value of value.
The value of this instance is equal to the value of value.
The value of this instance is greater than the value of value.

content.para: value is not a T:System.TimeSpan.
Any instance of T:System.TimeSpan, regardless of its value, is considered greater than null.
The value parameter must be an instance of T:System.TimeSpan or null; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The following code example compares several T:System.TimeSpan structures and other objects to a reference T:System.TimeSpan structure using the M:System.TimeSpan.CompareTo(System.Object) method.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or T:System.TimeSpan and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified T:System.TimeSpan object and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan object to compare to this instance.

returnValue.para: A signed number indicating the relative values of this instance and value.

entry.para: This instance is less than value.
This instance is equal to value.
This instance is greater than value.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IComparable`1 interface and performs slightly better than the M:System.TimeSpan.CompareTo(System.Object) method because it does not have to convert the value parameter to an object.
The following code example demonstrates generic and nongeneric versions of the Overload:System.TimeSpan.CompareTo method for several value and reference types.

summary.para: Returns a new T:System.TimeSpan object whose value is the absolute value of the current T:System.TimeSpan object.

returnValue.para: A new T:System.TimeSpan whose value is the absolute value of the current T:System.TimeSpan object.

content.para: The value of this instance is F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue.
The following code example applies the M:System.TimeSpan.Duration method to several T:System.TimeSpan objects.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether two instances of T:System.TimeSpan are equal.
Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified object.

content.para: An object to compare with this instance.

returnValue.para: true if value is a T:System.TimeSpan object that represents the same time interval as the current T:System.TimeSpan structure; otherwise, false.

content.para: The following code example compares several TimeSpan and other objects to a reference TimeSpan using the Equals method.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether two instances of T:System.TimeSpan are equal.
Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified T:System.TimeSpan object.

content.para: An T:System.TimeSpan object to compare with this instance.

returnValue.para: true if obj represents the same time interval as this instance; otherwise, false.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IEquatable`1 interface, and performs slightly better than M:System.TimeSpan.Equals(System.Object) because it does not have to convert the the obj parameter to an object.
The following code example demonstrates generic and nongeneric versions of the Overload:System.TimeSpan.CompareTo method for several value and reference types.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether two specified instances of T:System.TimeSpan are equal.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.
A TimeSpan.

returnValue.para: true if the values of t1 and t2 are equal; otherwise, false.

content.para: The following code example compares several T:System.TimeSpan objects to a reference T:System.TimeSpan object using the static M:System.TimeSpan.Equals(System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan) method.

summary.para: Returns a T:System.TimeSpan that represents a specified number of days, where the specification is accurate to the nearest millisecond.

content.para: A number of days, accurate to the nearest millisecond.

returnValue.para: A T:System.TimeSpan that represents value.

content.para: value is less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
value is equal to F:System.Double.NaN.

The value parameter is converted to milliseconds, which is converted to ticks, and that number of ticks is used to intialize the new T:System.TimeSpan. Therefore, value will only be considered accurate to the nearest millisecond.
If value is F:System.Double.PositiveInfinity, F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue is returned. If value is F:System.Double.NegativeInfinity, F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue is returned.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects using the M:System.TimeSpan.FromDays(System.Double) method.

summary.para: Returns a T:System.TimeSpan that represents a specified time, where the specification is in units of ticks.

The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects using the M:System.TimeSpan.FromTicks(System.Int64) method.

summary.para: Returns a hash code for this instance.

returnValue.para: A 32-bit signed integer hash code.

content.para: Two T:System.TimeSpan objects might have the same hash code even though they represent different time values.
The following code example generates the hash codes of several TimeSpan objects using the M:System.TimeSpan.GetHashCode method.

summary.para: Returns a T:System.TimeSpan whose value is the negated value of this instance.

returnValue.para: The same numeric value as this instance, but with the opposite sign.

content.para: The negated value of this instance cannot be represented by a T:System.TimeSpan; that is, the value of this instance is F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue.
The following code example applies the M:System.TimeSpan.Negate method to several TimeSpan objects.

A TimeSpan.

summary.para: Subtracts a specified T:System.TimeSpan from another specified T:System.TimeSpan.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.
A TimeSpan.

returnValue.para: A TimeSpan whose value is the result of the value of t1 minus the value of t2.

content.para: The return value is less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The following code example creates several pairs of TimeSpan objects and calculates their difference with the Subtraction operator.

summary.para: Returns a T:System.TimeSpan whose value is the negated value of the specified instance.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.

returnValue.para: A T:System.TimeSpan with the same numeric value as this instance, but the opposite sign.

content.para: The negated value of this instance cannot be represented by a T:System.TimeSpan; that is, the value of this instance is F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue.
The following code example applies the Unary Negation operator to several TimeSpan objects.

summary.para: Constructs a new T:System.TimeSpan object from a time interval specified in a string.

content.para: A string that specifies a time interval.

returnValue.para: A T:System.TimeSpan that corresponds to s.

content.para: s is null.
s has an invalid format.
s represents a number less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
-or-
At least one of the days, hours, minutes, or seconds components is outside its valid range.
The s parameter contains a time interval specification of the form:
[ws][-]{ d | [d.]hh:mm[:ss[.ff]] }[ws]

Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional; one selection from the list of alternatives enclosed in braces ({ and }) and separated by vertical bars (|) is required; colons and periods (: and .) are literal characters and required; other items are as follows.

entry.para: optional minus sign indicating a negative T:System.TimeSpan
optional fractional seconds, consisting of 1 to 7 decimal digits

content.para: The components of s must collectively specify a time interval greater than or equal to F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue and less than or equal to F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The following code example uses the Parse method to create TimeSpan objects from valid TimeSpan strings and to raise exceptions from invalid TimeSpan strings.

summary.para: Subtracts the specified T:System.TimeSpan from this instance.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan.

returnValue.para: A T:System.TimeSpan whose value is the result of the value of this instance minus the value of ts.

content.para: The return value is less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.
The return value must be between F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue and F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue; otherwise, an exception is thrown.
The return value is a new T:System.TimeSpan; the original T:System.TimeSpan is not modified.
The following code example creates several pairs of TimeSpan objects and calculates their difference with the Subtract method.

summary.para: Returns the string representation of the value of this instance.

returnValue.para: A string that represents the value of this instance. The return value is of the form:
[-][d.]hh:mm:ss[.ff]
Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional, colons and periods (: and.) are literal characters; and the other items are as follows.

entry.para: optional minus sign indicating a negative time
optional fractional seconds, from 1 to 7 decimal digits

alert.para: For more information about comparing the string representation of T:System.TimeSpan and Oracle data types, see article Q324577, "System.TimeSpan Does Not Match Oracle 9i INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND Data Type," in the Microsoft Knowledge Base at http://support.microsoft.com.

content.para: The return value of this method can be consumed by M:System.TimeSpan.Parse(System.String).
The following code example creates TimeSpan strings from TimeSpan objects using the ToString method.

summary.para: Constructs a new T:System.TimeSpan object from a time interval specified in a string. Parameters specify the time interval and the variable where the new T:System.TimeSpan object is returned.

content.para: A string that specifies a time interval.
When this method returns, contains an object that represents the time interval specified by s, or F:System.TimeSpan.Zero if the conversion failed. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

returnValue.para: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false. This operation returns false if the s parameter is null, has an invalid format,represents a time interval less than F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue or greater than F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue, or has at least one days, hours, minutes, or seconds component outside its valid range.

content.para: The M:System.TimeSpan.TryParse(System.String,System.TimeSpan@) method is like the M:System.TimeSpan.Parse(System.String) method, except the M:System.TimeSpan.TryParse(System.String,System.TimeSpan@) method does not throw an exception if the conversion fails.
The s parameter contains a time interval specification of the form:
[ws][-]{ d | d.hh:mm[:ss[.ff]] | hh:mm[:ss[.ff]] }[ws]

Items in square brackets ([ and ]) are optional. One selection from the list of alternatives enclosed in braces ({ and }) and separated by vertical bars (|) is required. Colons and periods (: and .) are literal characters and required. Other items are as follows.

entry.para: Optional minus sign indicating a negative T:System.TimeSpan.
Optional fractional seconds, consisting of 1 to 7 decimal digits.

content.para: The components of s must collectively specify a time interval greater than or equal to F:System.TimeSpan.MinValue and less than or equal to F:System.TimeSpan.MaxValue.

summary.para: Gets the number of whole days represented by the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The day component of this instance. The return value can be positive or negative.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. The value of the P:System.TimeSpan.Days property is the day component, d.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Days property of each.

summary.para: Gets the number of whole hours represented by the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The hour component of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure. The return value ranges from -23 through 23.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. The value of the P:System.TimeSpan.Hours property is the hours component, hh.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Hours property of each.

summary.para: Gets the number of whole milliseconds represented by the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The millisecond component of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure. The return value ranges from -999 through 999.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. The value of the P:System.TimeSpan.Milliseconds property is the fractional second component, ff.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Milliseconds property of each.

summary.para: Gets the number of whole minutes represented by the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The minute component of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure. The return value ranges from -59 through 59.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. The value of the P:System.TimeSpan.Minutes property is the minute component, mm.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Minutes property of each.

summary.para: Gets the number of whole seconds represented by the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The second component of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure. The return value ranges from -59 through 59.

content.para: A T:System.TimeSpan value can be represented as [-]d.hh:mm:ss.ff, where the optional minus sign indicates a negative time interval, the d component is days, hh is hours as measured on a 24-hour clock, mm is minutes, ss is seconds, and ff is fractions of a second. The value of the P:System.TimeSpan.Seconds property is the seconds component, ss.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Seconds property of each.

summary.para: Gets the number of ticks that represent the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure.

returnValue.para: The number of ticks contained in this instance.

content.para: The smallest unit of time is the tick, which is equal to 100 nanoseconds. A tick can be negative or positive.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the Ticks property of each.

summary.para: Gets the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure expressed in whole and fractional days.

returnValue.para: The total number of days represented by this instance.

content.para: This property converts the value of this instance from ticks to days. This number might include whole and fractional days.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the TotalDays property of each.

summary.para: Gets the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure expressed in whole and fractional hours.

returnValue.para: The total number of hours represented by this instance.

content.para: This property converts the value of this instance from ticks to hours. This number might include whole and fractional hours.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the TotalHours property of each.

summary.para: Gets the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure expressed in whole and fractional milliseconds.

returnValue.para: The total number of milliseconds represented by this instance.

content.para: This property converts the value of this instance from ticks to milliseconds. This number might include whole and fractional milliseconds.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the TotalMilliseconds property of each.

summary.para: Gets the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure expressed in whole and fractional minutes.

returnValue.para: The total number of minutes represented by this instance.

content.para: This property converts the value of this instance from ticks to minutes. This number might include whole and fractional minutes.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the TotalMinutes property of each.

summary.para: Gets the value of the current T:System.TimeSpan structure expressed in whole and fractional seconds.

returnValue.para: The total number of seconds represented by this instance.

content.para: This property converts the value of this instance from ticks to seconds. This number might include whole and fractional seconds.
The following code example creates several TimeSpan objects and displays the TotalSeconds property of each.
